title: Methods for Intrinsic Evaluation of Links in the Web of Data

author: Cristina Sarasua, Institute for Web Science and Technologies (WeST), University of Koblenz-Landau

segmentation: Hello everyone so I'm Christine and I'm from the University of Koblenz, Landau in the West Institute.
So we all know.

Know that the semantic web is very much about creating links, and one of the most important principles for linked data is obviously that we have to create links so that people can discover more things.
So that's what I will be talking about right now.
Um, so regarding this topic, there are already in the state of the art.
Several link analysis, basically saying or telling descriptive statistics like for example telling about the in and out degree of the data set.
So how many datasets other datasets linked to, for example, there are also statistics about the overall link predicate usage and also the overall link count.
So for example the Elodie stats is also reporting on this kind of.
Statistics and there are also other papers looking at link properties in the Elody cloud.
For example, looking at symmetry and transitivity, and this work was basically focused on life Sciences datasets.
When it comes to assessing links, there are like three major areas.
Some works have been looking at availability, so looking at the number of dead links that datasets contain.

Other works have been looking at how to assess and even improve semantic accuracy, so there was a work using network measures an also link properties count as a proxy for identifying the the semantic accuracy of links an there also several works around using microtask crowdsourcing for.
Improving the links out there.
And the last area in the state of the art is looking at the completeness of links.
So basically saying what is the percentage of entities in the source data set that are that is linked.
OK, so all these works really provide very insightful analysis on the data, but they don't completely answer the question.
To what extent do the existing links add more things to the source entities?
So this is what we.
Doing this work and what we do this because we want to help the data publisher who is already predisposed to improve her links.
So we are in the situation where the interlinking has been performed and the publisher wants to check what is the impact of the links on their source data set and wants to improve the links.
So we want to make the data publisher understand the impact of the links.
We also want to help spotting the weak points and also try to encourage.
Iterative maintenance of the links.

When we think of principles, we were trying to think of the most important principles for taint, interlinking and we came up with three.
So basically you can imagine this simple graph in one data set describing an entity which is the person Natasha NOI and some others other properties.
That story and then.

We would have an interlink to some other entity in another data set, which can be actually describing exactly the same person, so obviously one of the core principles of doing links is that we need to extend the entity description of the source, otherwise makes not not so much sense.
So in this case, for example, we would not gain anything in the description because we would just find that the other entity, the target entity, has exactly the same name as the source.
So we don't gain anything in.
Said if we were pointing to an entity that had another version for the name for this person, an other publications, and even another affiliation, and so on, then we do extended description.
So that's the first principle that we take into account in our work and.
We also, of course, if the description is also improved in terms of classification, this is better and then we have as a second Prince.
People that the Interlinks have to extend the entity connectivity.

We were.

We still don't gain anything in the description, but we can imagine that in the first data source this person Natasha NOI was changing affiliation, and then we want to update it from Stanford to Google in that case, even if we don't gain anything as as the description of the entity we would like to have them linked.
So that we can update all the data in Cascade.
And the more entities we connect to, the better, of course.
And the third principle that we take into account is basically that we should be increasing the number of vocabularies used both in the in the links and also in the description.
So if we.
Addnew properties and knew classes coming from different vocabularies.
Then it's something that the quality assessment for the link should acknowledge.
So what we did in our framework that we implemented part of the Coalfish framework that we are developing in.

Entities.
And once we create different views of the data, what we try to do is to measure what each source entity gains.
For each of these views, so for the description for the connectivity and for the classification.
And we tried to signal redundancy.

So what we do is we measure the gain by looking at the diversity of this view, including the links and compare it to the diversity of this view without the links and for diversity we use the standard Shannon entropy and we do this for any data on any vocabulary.
So for example if we had in the source data set the description that the entity has named Natasha Noy and likes I SWC.
